title: About
text:
About this site # About Me
I am a full time MPH student at JHU, and I am interested in the intersection between public health, management and clinical medicine.

title: Example Analysis
text:
This analysis follows guidance from a project example (Hicks 2025).
Some insights were generated using AI assistance (OpenAI 2025).
We also included a personal image for illustration purposes (Co 2024).
About this site: A data analysis page called ‘Example analysis’. The requirements for this webpage are the following:

You must describe what is the question you aim to answer with the data and data analysis.

Grade by Subject.

You must describe who is the intended audience for the data analysis.

Class TAs.

You must describe and link to where the original data come from that you chose.

I used the curl command to get the database from this particular page: curl -L -o students.csv https://raw.githubusercontent.com/stephaniehicks/jhustatprogramming2025/main/projects/01-project/students.csv
This came from Part 2 of Project 1 of the course: https://www.stephaniehicks.com/jhustatprogramming2025/projects/01-project/index.html

You must include a link to a data dictionary for the data or create one inside the webpage.

Below is the data dictionary for this data frame.

data_dictionary <- data.frame(
  Variable = c("ID", "Name", "Age", "Gender", "Grade", "Subject"),
  Description = c("ID", "Name", "Age", "Gender", "Grade", "Subject"),
  Type = c("Character", "Character", "Numeric", "Character", "Numeric", "Character"),
  stringsAsFactors = FALSE
)
print(data_dictionary)

  Variable Description      Type
1       ID          ID Character
2     Name        Name Character
3      Age         Age   Numeric
4   Gender      Gender Character
5    Grade       Grade   Numeric
6  Subject     Subject Character



Your analysis must include some minimal form of data wrangling with you using at least five different functions from dplyr or tidyr.


library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.2     ✔ tibble    3.3.0
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.1.0     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

students <- read.csv("students.csv")
print(students)

   ID    Name Age Gender Grade Subject
1   1   Alice  20      F    88    Math
2   2     Bob  22      M    76 History
3   3 Charlie  23      M    90    Math
4   4   Diana  21      F    85 Science
5   5     Eve  20      F    92    Math
6   6   Frank  22      M    72 History
7   7   Grace  23      F    78 Science
8   8   Heidi  21      F    88    Math
9   9    Ivan  20      M    85 Science
10 10    Judy  22      F    79 History

#Mutate
students <- students %>%
  mutate(Subject = ifelse(Subject == "Math", "Mathematics", Subject))
print (students)

   ID    Name Age Gender Grade     Subject
1   1   Alice  20      F    88 Mathematics
2   2     Bob  22      M    76     History
3   3 Charlie  23      M    90 Mathematics
4   4   Diana  21      F    85     Science
5   5     Eve  20      F    92 Mathematics
6   6   Frank  22      M    72     History
7   7   Grace  23      F    78     Science
8   8   Heidi  21      F    88 Mathematics
9   9    Ivan  20      M    85     Science
10 10    Judy  22      F    79     History

#Group_by
#Summarise
#Mean
students_summary <- students %>%
  group_by(Subject) %>%
  summarise(Average_Grade = mean(Grade), Count = n())
print (students_summary)

# A tibble: 3 × 3
  Subject     Average_Grade Count
  <chr>               <dbl> <int>
1 History              75.7     3
2 Mathematics          89.5     4
3 Science              82.7     3

#Arrange
students_sorted <- students%>%
  arrange(desc(Grade))
print(students_sorted)

   ID    Name Age Gender Grade     Subject
1   5     Eve  20      F    92 Mathematics
2   3 Charlie  23      M    90 Mathematics
3   1   Alice  20      F    88 Mathematics
4   8   Heidi  21      F    88 Mathematics
5   4   Diana  21      F    85     Science
6   9    Ivan  20      M    85     Science
7  10    Judy  22      F    79     History
8   7   Grace  23      F    78     Science
9   2     Bob  22      M    76     History
10  6   Frank  22      M    72     History

#Filter
students_filtered <- students %>%
  filter(Grade > 80)
print(students_filtered)

  ID    Name Age Gender Grade     Subject
1  1   Alice  20      F    88 Mathematics
2  3 Charlie  23      M    90 Mathematics
3  4   Diana  21      F    85     Science
4  5     Eve  20      F    92 Mathematics
5  8   Heidi  21      F    88 Mathematics
6  9    Ivan  20      M    85     Science



Your analysis should include at least three plots with you using at least three different geom_() functions from ggplot2 (or another package with geom_() functions).







Note



Here are the graphs



library(ggplot2)

ggplot(students_summary, aes(Subject, Average_Grade, fill = Subject)) +
  geom_col() +
  labs(
    title = "Average Grade by Subject",
    subtitle = "Comparison of mean grades across all subjects",
    x = "Subject",
    y = "Average Grade"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()







ggplot(students_summary, aes(x = Subject, y = Average_Grade, group = 1)) +
  geom_line() +
  geom_point() +
  labs(
    title = "Average Grade Trend by Subject",
    subtitle = "Line chart showing how average grades vary by subject",
    x = "Subject",
    y = "Average Grade"
  ) +
  theme_light()







ggplot(students, aes(Subject, Grade, fill = Subject)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  labs(
    title = "Grade Distribution by Subject",
    subtitle = "Boxplots showing spread and outliers in student grades",
    x = "Subject",
    y = "Grade"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()









Plots should have titles, subtitles, captions, and human-understandable axis labels.

See above, for labels

At least one plot should using a type of faceting (facet_grid() or facet_wrap()).


ggplot(students, aes(x = Subject, y = Grade, fill = Subject)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  facet_wrap(~ Gender) + 
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(
    title = "Grades by Subject and Gender",
    subtitle = "Boxplots showing grade distribution across subjects"
  )









Your analysis must include one image or table (not one you created yourself, but one you have saved locally or one from the web).







Tip



In summary, it is better to be a cat.



library(knitr)
include_graphics("images/2.jpg")









Your analysis must include at least two different callout blocks. see above
Your analysis must include a .bib file, which you use to reference at least three unique citations. For example, it could be to a website or paper from where the original data came from or it could be to a paper describing a method you are using to analyze the data. see above
Your analysis must include the use of at least 1 margin content.



Note: This is a margin note. Attempt 3

At the end of the data analysis, list out each of the functions you used from each of the packages (dplyr, tidyr, and ggplot2) to help the TA with respect to making sure you met all the requirements described above.

tidyverse: mutate, group_by, summarise, arrange, filter ggplot: geom_boxplot(), geom_col(), geom_line(), geom_point(), geom_boxplot
Meow




References

Co, Eimee. 2024. “Chill.”


Hicks, Stephanie. 2025. “Project 01: Data Analysis.” 2025. https://www.stephaniehicks.com/jhustatprogramming2025/projects/01-project/index.html.


OpenAI. 2025. “ChatGPT.” https://openai.com/chatgpt.

title: MyWebsite
text:
Eimee Co
Hi! I’m Eimee. I enjoy eating, sleeping and cats.



Something I enjoy



Link to your GitHub repository: https://github.com/Esprit-Cat/biostat777-intro-eimee-co/tree/main
Link to your deployed website: https://esprit-cat.github.io/biostat777-intro-eimee-co/exampleanalysis.html

title: Project 1
text:
Consider the dataset called students.csv with the following contents:
ID,Name,Age,Gender,Grade,Subject
1,Alice,20,F,88,Math
2,Bob,22,M,76,History
3,Charlie,23,M,90,Math
4,Diana,21,F,85,Science
5,Eve,20,F,92,Math
6,Frank,22,M,72,History
7,Grace,23,F,78,Science
8,Heidi,21,F,88,Math
9,Ivan,20,M,85,Science
10,Judy,22,F,79,History

Use wget or curl to download the students.csv file locally from here.


# Add your solution here
curl -L -o students.csv https://raw.githubusercontent.com/stephaniehicks/jhustatprogramming2025/main/projects/01-project/students.csv

  % Total    % Received % Xferd  Average Speed   Time    Time     Time  Current
                                 Dload  Upload   Total   Spent    Left  Speed

  0     0    0     0    0     0      0      0 --:--:-- --:--:-- --:--:--     0
100   257  100   257    0     0   4528      0 --:--:-- --:--:-- --:--:--  4589



Display the contents of the students.csv file using the cat command.


# Add your solution here
cat students.csv

ID,Name,Age,Gender,Grade,Subject
1,Alice,20,F,88,Math
2,Bob,22,M,76,History
3,Charlie,23,M,90,Math
4,Diana,21,F,85,Science
5,Eve,20,F,92,Math
6,Frank,22,M,72,History
7,Grace,23,F,78,Science
8,Heidi,21,F,88,Math
9,Ivan,20,M,85,Science
10,Judy,22,F,79,History



Display only the first 5 lines of the file using head to show the first few lines.


# Add your solution here
head -n 5 students.csv

ID,Name,Age,Gender,Grade,Subject
1,Alice,20,F,88,Math
2,Bob,22,M,76,History
3,Charlie,23,M,90,Math
4,Diana,21,F,85,Science



Display only the last 3 lines of the file using tail to show the last few lines.


# Add your solution here
tail -n 3 students.csv

8,Heidi,21,F,88,Math
9,Ivan,20,M,85,Science
10,Judy,22,F,79,History



Count the number of lines in the file using the wc command to count the lines.


# Add your solution here
wc students.csv

      10      11     257 students.csv



Find all students who are taking “Math” as a subject using grep to filter lines with the subject “Math”.


# Add your solution here
grep "Math" students.csv

1,Alice,20,F,88,Math
3,Charlie,23,M,90,Math
5,Eve,20,F,92,Math
8,Heidi,21,F,88,Math



Find all female students using grep or awk to filter based on gender.


# Add your solution here
awk -F',' '$4=="F"' students.csv

1,Alice,20,F,88,Math
4,Diana,21,F,85,Science
5,Eve,20,F,92,Math
7,Grace,23,F,78,Science
8,Heidi,21,F,88,Math
10,Judy,22,F,79,History



Sort the file by the students’ ages in ascending order. Use sort to order by the “Age” column.


# Add your solution here
sort -t',' -k3,3n students.csv

ID,Name,Age,Gender,Grade,Subject
1,Alice,20,F,88,Math
5,Eve,20,F,92,Math
9,Ivan,20,M,85,Science
4,Diana,21,F,85,Science
8,Heidi,21,F,88,Math
10,Judy,22,F,79,History
2,Bob,22,M,76,History
6,Frank,22,M,72,History
3,Charlie,23,M,90,Math
7,Grace,23,F,78,Science



Find the unique subjects listed in the file. Use cut, sort, and uniq to extract unique subjects.


# Add your solution here
cut -d',' -f6 students.csv | sort | uniq

History
Math
Science
Subject



Calculate the average grade of the students. Use awk to sum the grades and divide by the number of students.


# Add your solution here
awk -F',' 'NR>1 {sum = sum + $5; count = count + 1} END {print "Average grade:", sum/count}' students.csv

Average grade: 83.3



Replace all occurrences of “Math” with “Mathematics” in the file. Use sed to perform the replacement.


# Add your solution here
sed 's/Math/Mathematics/g' students.csv

ID,Name,Age,Gender,Grade,Subject
1,Alice,20,F,88,Mathematics
2,Bob,22,M,76,History
3,Charlie,23,M,90,Mathematics
4,Diana,21,F,85,Science
5,Eve,20,F,92,Mathematics
6,Frank,22,M,72,History
7,Grace,23,F,78,Science
8,Heidi,21,F,88,Mathematics
9,Ivan,20,M,85,Science
10,Judy,22,F,79,History



Put all the commands into a shell script (.sh) file and run the command below to show the output from all the commands together.


# Add your solution here 
touch students_analysis.sh
chmod +x students_analysis.sh
